I work in the heart surgery business now for 26 years, involved with 4000 procedures , and I can tell you I bought $400,000 worth of this stock. Of course, hope I'm not wrong right? It takes a long time to get a valve to market, and the Edwards Sapien TAVR valve has superb market share and results. We did 15, then 50 and then 150 last year. Patients are learning about it , and that's what Mick Jagger got. I have great confidence in this stock, and also Medtronic, another holding. I bought in EW at 190, and again at 230. I don't think in 5 years I'll be doing Aortic Valve Replacements, just repairs or combination procedures if the heart is already going to be exposed. Also, the newer coatings on all valves are so much improved from the 80's and 90's one can expect a valve to last your lifetime. EW is also a really good company with lots of other product lines. I feel the same way as I did about Intuitive Surgical.

Pleased to see the settling of the longstanding Abbott v. Edwards transcatheter mitral valve lawsuit. As you can imagine if you are already using the Edwards Sapien aortic valve system it is an easy transition to add the PASCAL mitral repair device to your toolkit for most cathlabs and ORs.

Once again the yahoos at Yahoo remain asleep at the switch regarding important news updates......Here's a snippet from a BofA/Merrill Lynch report issued yesterday regarding restart of EW's Mitral study:.....Mitral update at CRTWe are attending the CRT conference in Washington DC this weekend. On Sunday, EW’s lead investigators provided a surprisingly positive update on EW’s CardiAQ program by announcing that EW will restart enrollment in its mitral replacement trials in Q2. Recall that it was only a few weeks ago on EW’s Q4 call that EW announced that these same trials had been paused. This suggests that 2018 approval in Europe remains possible if all goes well with the studies. We think the delay in the program was a major reason why EW sold off following the Q4 call.The presentation slide from one of EW’s lead investigators updating the CRT attendees on the status of EW‘s CardiAQ mitral early feasibility studies stated: “brief pause in case scheduling while key clinical learnings were being implemented, but full patient screening is now continuing in anticipation of Q2 cases.” The clear message from CRT was that the issue that caused the pause that EW announced on its Q4 earnings call has been resolved. Comments from the podium at CRT suggest the issue had to do with how the centers were being trained. EW’s 10-K on Friday also provided an update on the status of CardiAQ. The 10-K language read “the Company disclosed in early February 2017 that it had voluntarily paused enrollment in its clinical trials for the Edwards- CardiAQ valve to perform further design validation testing on a feature of the valve.This testing has been completed and, in collaboration with clinical investigators, the Company has decided to resume screening patients for enrollment in its clinical trials.” Cases will resume in Q2, which suggests 2018 approval in Europe remains a possibility. The other key message from CRT on EW’s CardiAQ mitral technology was that improvements to the size and deliverability of the device are happening now and should be available soon in Europe. This is key as the current system remains technically challenging, especially with the TS approach.

Only 6 months to the release of the culmination of the TAVR trials EARLY TAVR which studies aortic valve replacement percutaneously in patients who have no symptoms i.e no fainting, chest pain or congestive heart failure. Looking at what happened with PARTNER I: 11$ - 16$ (Oct 2010), PARTNER II: 19 - 38 dollars (Apr 2016), and most recently PARTNER III (detailed below in the conversations). EARLY TAVR's release is the last chance investors may get to see a meteoric jump in EW. While growth and profits will continue - it would be wise not to miss this catalyst in December 2021. Just listened to the EW conference call, management mentioned several times that there are a number of "tailwinds" going into next year that will drive their sales/eps growth and mentioned they expects margins to improve and costs to go down. They have $1.2 Billion overseas that they can not currently use for buybacks but are trying to figure out a way to do that. They will be buying back stock and reducing share count when the opportunity presents itself(maybe tomorrow?) and expect continued strong growth as more trial data comes out in transcatheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR) in medium to lower risk populations. The company will present some innovative new products that they will expect will drive growth and new opportunities at their Analyst Day in December. They reiterated guidance and said everything is on track. It seems like a no brainer that EW will continue to grow strongly as TAVR replaces open heart surgery, which is more expensive, riskier, and has much greater recovery time. What do you think patients would prefer?? To get their chest sawed in half or to have a small incision and no actual surgery with EW's device?? They will pick TAVR EVERY single time and EW is the dominant player in the field
